member.name: T:Accord.Music.Sets.IMusicalSet`1
member.remarks:
Musical set theory deals with collections of pitches and pitch classes, which may be ordered or unordered, and which can be related by musical operations such as transposition, inversion, and complementation. The methods of musical set theory are sometimes applied to the analysis of rhythm as well.
References: - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Set_theory_(music)

member.name: T:Accord.Music.Sets.IntervalVector
member.summary: An interval vector is an array that expresses the intervallic content of a pitch-class set.
member.remarks:
In 12 equal temperament the interval vector has six digits, with each digit standing for the number of times an interval class appears in the set. (Interval classes, not regular intervals, must be used, in order that the interval vector remains the same, regardless of the set's permutation or vertical arrangement.)
The interval classes represented by each digit ascend from left to right. That is:
1) minor seconds/major sevenths (1 or 11 semitones) 2) major seconds/minor sevenths (2 or 10 semitones) 3) minor thirds/major sixths (3 or 9 semitones) 4) major thirds/minor sixths (4 or 8 semitones) 5) perfect fourths/perfect fifths (5 or 7 semitones) 6) tritones (6 semitones) (The tritone is inversionally related to itself.)
Interval class 0 (representing unisons and octaves) is omitted.

members.member:
Scale is a group of musical notes ordered by pitch.
In music, a scale is a group of musical notes collected in ascending and descending order, that provides material for or is used to conveniently represent part or all of a musical work including melody and/or harmony. Scales are ordered in pitch or pitch class, with their ordering providing a measure of musical distance.
Major scales: http://musiced.about.com/od/lessonsandtips/qt/scales.htm a scale is a pitch class *collection*.

member.name: P:Accord.Music.Scales.Scale.Tonic
member.summary: Gets or sets the tonic note for the scale.
member.remarks: The tonic is the central and most stable note of the scale

member.name: T:Accord.Music.Accidental
member.remarks: In music, an accidental is a note whose pitch (or pitch class) is not a member of a scale or mode indicated by the most recently applied key signature. In musical notation, the symbols used to mark such notes, sharps (#), flats (b), and naturals may also be called accidentals.

member.name: T:Accord.Music.AccidentalEx
member.summary: Extension methods for Accidentals from the Accidental Enumeration.

member.name: T:Accord.Music.Chord
member.remarks: References: - http://www.smithfowler.org/music/Chord_Formulas.htm

member.name: T:Accord.Music.NoteName
member.summary: Note names for the (seven-note) diatonic major scale.
member.remarks: The enum values are the distance between the note and C in semitones. The Diatonic Major Scale is do-re-mi-fa-so-la-si-(do).

member.name: M:Accord.Music.Note.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.param: The integer notation value for the note.

member.name: M:Accord.Music.Note.GetPitch
member.summary: Gets the note's pitch in the default octave.

member.name: M:Accord.Music.Note.GetPitch(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the note's pitch in a given octave.

member.name: M:Accord.Music.Note.Equals(System.Object)
member.summary: Compares if the note has the same letter-name, and accidental, disregarding any enharmonic equivalence information, as another object.

member.name: M:Accord.Music.Note.Equals(Accord.Music.Note)
member.summary: Compares if the note has the same letter-name, and accidental, disregarding any enharmonic equivalence information, as another note.
member.returns: Returns true if the two are equal, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Accord.Music.Note.EnharmonicEquals(Accord.Music.Note)
member.summary: Compares if the notes are enharmonic equivalents, having the same pitch despite having different names.
member.returns: Returns true if the two are equivalent, false otherwise.

member.name: P:Accord.Music.Note.Class
member.summary: Gets the value of the note in integer notation.

member.name: T:Accord.Music.IntervalClass
member.remarks: In musical set theory, an interval class is the shortest distance in pitch class space between two unordered pitch classes.

member.name: T:Accord.Music.StandardKeySignature
member.remarks: Unlike the KeySignature class, this class is associated with a particular key.

member.name: T:Accord.Music.KeySignature
member.summary: A series of sharp or flat symbols placed on the staff.
member.remarks: A key signature is a series of sharp or flat symbols placed on the staff, designating notes that are to be consistently played one semitone higher or lower than the equivalent natural notes unless otherwise altered with an accidental.

member.name: P:Accord.Music.KeySignature.Item(Accord.Music.NoteName)
member.summary: Gets the accidental designated for a note by this signature.

member.name: T:Accord.Music.TimeSignature
member.remarks: Currently only supports rational signatures.

member.name: T:Accord.Music.Clef
member.summary: A clef is a musical symbol used to indicate the pitch of written notes.
member.remarks: Placed on one of the lines at the beginning of the staff, it indicates the name and pitch of the notes on that line. This line serves as a reference point by which the names of the notes on any other line or space of the staff may be determined.

member.name: M:Accord.Music.Clef.#ctor(System.String,Accord.Music.Pitch,System.Int32)
member.param: The pitch associated with the Clef.
The reference line in where the associated pitch is located.

member.name: M:Accord.Music.Clef.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.Int32)
member.param: The pitch associated with the Clef.
The reference line in where the associated pitch is located.

member.name: P:Accord.Music.Clef.Name
member.summary: Gets the name for the Clef.

member.name: P:Accord.Music.Clef.Pitch
member.summary: Gets the pitch of the reference line.

member.name: P:Accord.Music.Clef.Line
member.summary: Gets the reference line for the pitch associated with this Clef.

member.name: T:Accord.Music.IntervalName
member.remarks: The interval name is given by the difference between two noter names, without considering the distance in semitones.

member.name: T:Accord.Music.Interval
member.remarks: http://www.knowledgerush.com/kr/encyclopedia/Interval_(music)/

member.name: M:Accord.Music.Interval.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Intervals are often abbreviated with a P for perfect, m for minor, M for major, d for diminished, A for augmented, followed by the diatonic interval number. The indication M and P are often omitted. The octave is P8, and a unison is usually referred to simply as "a unison" but can be labeled P1. The tritone, an augmented fourth or diminished fifth is often Ï€ or TT.
member.remarks: Examples: m1, m2, M3, TT, P8, A4, T, S, H, W, 1, 2, 3

member.name: P:Accord.Music.Interval.Name
member.summary: Gets the simple diatonic interval name.

member.name: T:Accord.Music.PitchClass
member.summary: A pitch class is a set of all pitches that are a whole number of octaves apart, e.g., the pitch class C consists of the Cs in all octaves.
member.remarks: In standard Western equal temperament, distinct spellings can refer to the same sounding object: B#3, C4, and D4 all refer to the same pitch, hence share the same chroma, and therefore belong to the same pitch class; a phenomenon called enharmonic equivalence.

member.name: M:Accord.Music.PitchClass.#ctor(Accord.Music.Note)
member.param: The base note for the class.

member.name: P:Accord.Music.PitchClass.Label
member.summary: Gets the integer label for the pitch class.

member.name: P:Accord.Music.PitchClass.Enharmonics
member.summary: The base note for the pitch class.

member.name: T:Accord.Music.Pitch
member.summary: Represents a pitch in Scientific Pitch Notation.
member.remarks: Scientific pitch notation is one of several methods that name the notes of the standard Western chromatic scale by combining a letter-name, accidentals, and a number identifying the pitch's octave.

member.name: M:Accord.Music.Pitch.#ctor(Accord.Music.NoteName,System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructs a new pitch. Default accidental is none.

member.name: M:Accord.Music.Pitch.#ctor(Accord.Music.PitchClass,System.Int32)
member.param: The pitch class for the pitch.

member.name: M:Accord.Music.Pitch.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.param: The number of semitones starting from C(-1) that identifies the pitch in the MIDI system.

member.name: M:Accord.Music.Pitch.#ctor(System.String)
member.param: The text symbol for the pitch. i.e.: C#1, Db3, G5, A##97, Ab-73

member.name: M:Accord.Music.Pitch.Equals(System.Object)
member.summary: Compares if the pitch has the same letter-name, accidental and octave, disregarding enharmonic equivalence information, as another object.

member.name: M:Accord.Music.Pitch.EnharmonicEquals(Accord.Music.Pitch)
member.summary: Compares if the pitch is enharmonically equivalent to another pitch.
member.returns: Returns true if the two are equivalent, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Accord.Music.Pitch.Equals(Accord.Music.Pitch)
member.summary: Compares if the pitch has the same letter-name, accidental and octave, disregarding enharmonic equivalence information, as another object.
member.returns: Returns true if the two are equivalent, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Accord.Music.Pitch.EnharmonicCompareTo(Accord.Music.Pitch)
member.summary: Compares if the pitch is enharmonically equivalent to another pitch.

member.summary: Gets or sets the octave for the pitch.

member.name: P:Accord.Music.Pitch.Note
member.summary: Gets the note for this pitch.

member.name: P:Accord.Music.Pitch.Frequency
member.summary: Gets or sets a pitch frequency. Octave, letter-name, and accidentals will change automatically to reflect the new frequency.

member.name: P:Accord.Music.Pitch.Distance
member.summary: The negative or positive distance, in semitones, from middle C (C4).

member.name: P:Accord.Music.Pitch.Number
member.summary: The MIDI number for the pitch.
member.remarks: The MIDI number is the distance from C(-1) and identifies pitches without considering any information about enharmonics equivalents.

member.name: T:Accord.Music.NoteSign
member.remarks: In standard notation, a single musical sound is written as a note. The two most important things a written piece of music needs to tell you about a note are its pitch - how high or low it is - and its duration - how long it lasts.

member.name: M:Accord.Music.NoteSign.Rest(Accord.Music.Duration)
member.summary: Named constructor for a new rest sign.

member.name: P:Accord.Music.NoteSign.Pitch
member.summary: Gets or sets the pitch of the note.
member.remarks: The pitch contains information about note, octave and frequency.

member.name: P:Accord.Music.NoteSign.Value
member.summary: Gets or sets the duration of the note.

member.name: P:Accord.Music.NoteSign.Augmentation
member.summary: Gets or sets the current number of duration augmentation dots for the note.

member.name: P:Accord.Music.NoteSign.IsRest
member.summary: Gets a value indicating if the sign is a rest.

member.name: P:Accord.Music.NoteSign.Duration
member.summary: Computes the actual duration for the note considering the augmentation effects.
